tossups.question: In an essay, this writer claims that Heinrich von Kleist belongs to “an A league of writers”; that essay is part of a collection of letters between this writer and Paul Auster titled Here and Now. A doctor in a novel by this author bonds with a prisoner who refuses to eat and escapes to Sea Point. Another novel by this author opens with the protagonist visiting the prostitute Soraya. That character’s hair is later set on (*) fire by three home invaders, who rape his daughter Lucy. A novel by this author follows a cleft-lipped man who carries his mother in a wheelbarrow to escape war. Professor David Lurie is fired for having illicit relationships with a student in a novel by this author. For 10 points, name this author of Life & Times of Michael K and Disgrace.

A collaborative piece by six artists from this nation features bike parts, a battered bugle, and a clock all buried in sand under the plastic roof of the title Patio and Pavilion. An artist from this nation created a series of 18 works featuring two central forms created from images of mass media that he called “Telemaths.” Artists from this nation’s Independent Group, such as John McHale, staged the (*) This is Tomorrow exhibition, which introduced Pop Art. A cinema playing The Jazz Singer, an advertisement from Ladies Home Journal, and a nude man holding a massive lollipop appear in the best-known work by an artist from this nation. For 10 points, name this home country of Richard Hamilton and the modern graffiti artist Banksy.
tossups.answer: United Kingdom [or UK or Great Britain or Britain; accept England or Scotland] This is Tomorrow; Telemaths are a series by John McHale)

tossups.question: In an Arthurian romance, Yvain travels to one of these locations and summons the knight Esclados by pouring water from a spring onto an enchanted stone. In English folklore, one of these places near Windsor is guarded by the ghost Herne. The Lady of the Lake banishes Merlin to one of these places named Broceliande, which is held to be home to Merlin's Tomb. One resident of one of these locations in England is believed to have shot an (*) arrow out of a window after he was bled to death by the Prioress. That resident of one of these locations was the leader of a group that included Will Scarlet and Little John. For 10 points, name this type of location, one of which named Sherwood is home to Robin Hood and his Merry Men.
tossups.answer: forest [accept woods, woodlands, groves or any similar answers; accept specific forests; accept any answer indicating a grouping of trees; prompt on a tree with "in what sort of location?"]

tossups.question: A princess from this house was burned alive after accidentally lighting her crinoline dress on fire with a cigarette she was hiding from her father. Maximilian O’Donnell saved a king of this house from an assassination attempt, though the king’s thick collar also helped block the knife of the assassin. A prince of this house killed himself and his wife Mary Vetsera while at a hunting lodge in (*) Mayerling. A woman who married into this house was killed by Luigi Lucheni at Lake Geneva. Charles II of Spain suffered from this house’s namesake “jaw”, which likely developed due to inbreeding. For 10 points, name this long-ruling house of the Holy Roman Empire and eventually just Austria.
tossups.answer: House of Habsburg (the first person is Archduchess Mathilde of Austria)

tossups.question: Impaired production of this compound in the Arabidopsis mutant Procuste1 is rescued by a second mutation in the transmembrane kinase Theseus1. The herbicide isoxaben targets this compound’s synthase. In the multi-net growth hypothesis, sheets of this compound rotate at increasingly longitudinal angles. This compound is synthesized by an enzyme with a UDP-glucose substrate and six subunits arranged into rosettes. During cell growth, (*) microfibrils of this compound are arranged transversely along the axis of elongation and are strengthened by pectin and lignin. In its simplest form, this compound consists of beta [1,4] linked glucan chains. For 10 points, name this polysaccharide that is the major component of plant cell walls.

At a military symposium in this decade, women were sexually harassed while walking through a “gauntlet” in the Las Vegas Hilton. During this decade, Defense Secretary Les Aspin resigned partly due to the Tailhook Scandal. Surgeon General Jocelyn Elders was fired during this decade for encouraging education about masturbation. Kathleen Willey reportedly exited the Oval Office in a “disheveled” state according to testimony from (*) Linda Tripp in this decade. During this decade, the suicide of Vince Foster was investigated by Kenneth Starr, who also investigated the Whitewater Development Corporation. For 10 points, name this decade, during which the president claimed he “did not have sexual relations” with Monica Lewinsky.

In an essay titled "Pity the sad legacy of" this person, one thinker argued that "We are witnessing the postmodern version of the full scale gangsterization of the world." In the lecture "Speaking in Tongues," Zadie Smith compared this person to Eliza Doolittle and describes this person's voice at different ages. Cornel West has repeatedly attacked Ta-Nehisi Coates for his support of this (*) politician's policies. This politician described his life up to his enrollment at Harvard Law School in the memoir Dreams of My Father. Shepherd Fairey designed a red, beige, and blue poster depicting this politician with the word "Hope" for this politician's 2008 campaign. For 10 points, name this subject of the Coates essay "My President Was Black."
tossups.answer: Barack Obama [or Barack Hussein Obama II]

tossups.question: A collection of vocal works from this country contains excerpts from the opera The Abduction of Cephalus and is one of the first treatises on the proper performance of monodies. Although not Austria, Johannes Fux depicted himself in dialogue with a composer from this country in the second section of his Gradus ad Parnassum. Words take precedence over harmony in a form of composition termed the “second style” that developed in this country. A composer from this country wrote works such as Tenebrae Responsoria that feature highly atypical (*) chromatic harmonies - that composer notably killed his wife and her lover. Vespers of the Blessed Virgin was written by a composer from this country, where another composer wrote a mass to prevent the banning of polyphony. For 10 points, name this modern-day country home to Monteverdi and Palestrina.

In 2D models, this phenomenon occurs at non-zero values of the amplitude for the order parameter. This phenomenon is weakly suppressed by periodic oscillations in a critical value in the Little-Parks effect. The semi-fluxon is a half integer vortex carrying this phenomenon at the zero-pi boundary of a Josephson junctions. Differences in materials exhibiting this phenomenon are described by the ratio of (*) coherence length to London penetration depth. Cuprates, such as YBCO, are known for exhibiting this phenomenon above temperatures traditionally predicted by BCS theory. Type I materials exhibiting this phenomenon expel magnetic fields in the Meissner effect. For 10 points, name this phenomenon in materials with zero electrical resistance.

In De Sensibus, Theophrastus lists this philosopher last instead of Plato, because this figure believed that knowledge came from both similarity and contrast. This philosopher argued that neither "nothing" nor "thing" exist more than each other and Aristotle reported this philosopher as claiming that "necessity drives change." This successor of Leucippus was known as the (*) "laughing philosopher" and argued that the void was a temporarily empty space that is eventually filled by a type of object he helped define. Unlike Epicurus, this thinker argued that those indivisible bits of matter were forced to move in straight lines. For 10 points, name this pre-Socratic philosopher, who outlined the theory of atomism.

In this country, a tax increase on beer, cars, tobacco, and everything fun was formulated by Arnold Nordmeyer and called the “Black Budget.” During a debate on nuclear weapons, a leader of this country told his opponent he could “smell the uranium on your breath.” Fernando Pereira was killed during an attack in this country termed Operation Satanic. Economic policies called (*) Ruthanasia, Rogernomics, and Think Big were implemented in this country. This country was the site of the bombing of the Greenpeace ship Rainbow Warrior. Norman Kirk established a national holiday named for an 1840 treaty signed by this country’s indigenous people. For 10 points, name this country, where the Treaty of Waitangi was signed by the Maōri.

One epic poem from this country is based on a J.P.C. de Florian novel about Numa Pompelius. According to Henry Adams Bellows, one poem from this country was reduced to only 22 stanzas due to the absence of the Great Lacuna. Another poem from this country features the men High, Just-as-High, and Third answering questions from a disguised (*) King Gylfi. In another poem from this country, a god stabs a woman with a "sleeping thorn" and earlier placed a sword in a sacred oak. That poem from this country also depicts a hero flying through a ring of fire to rescue that aforementioned woman, Brynhild. For 10 points, the Prose and Poetic Eddas were written in what island country, the home of Snorri Sturluson?

A di-substituted one of these compounds reacts with an ortho-iodo-aniline in the Larock indole synthesis. The Bailey system describes a high temperature reaction involving two of these compounds and a mixture of tungsten and silicon oxide, which was improved using a molybdenum catalyst by Montreux. A strong base like potassium hydride can be added to isomerize an internal example of this functional group to a terminal position in a namesake (*) “zipper” reaction. A di-bromo intermediate forms when synthesizing one of these compounds from an aldehyde in the Corey-Fuchs reaction. Reacting one of these compounds with Lindlar’s catalyst will produce an alkene. For 10 points, name these compounds with carbon-carbon triple bonds.
tossups.answer: alkynes [prompt on hydrocarbons; do not accept alkene or alkane]

tossups.question: This author’s father confiscated the only manuscript of a novella about a woman who tells Woodville about her father confessing his love for her. In a novel by this author, Lord Raymond leads a failed siege of Constantinople. A character created by this author stops reading about natural philosophy after seeing lightning destroy an oak tree, but resumes studying it at the University of (*) Ingolstadt. Lionel Verney is the only person to survive a plague in the year 2100 in her novel The Last Man. The title character of this author’s most famous novel is found on an ice floe in the North Pole by the ship captain Robert Walton. Henry Clerval and Elizabeth Lavenza are victims of that unnamed character created by this author in a novel subtitled The Modern Prometheus. For 10 points, name this author of Frankenstein.
tossups.answer: Mary Shelley [or Mary Wollstonecraft Shelley; or Mary Godwin; the novella in the first line is Mathilda]

tossups.question: The founder of this religion was born in a cow pen and was raised by a monk known for his ownership of a printing press. One text used in this religion has a name translating Liberation Through Hearing During the Intermediate State and describes the afterlife of this religion. This religion venerates the Nechung oracle, who helps guide the process of phowa. Leaders of this religion are known as (*) tulkus and the highest female title in this religion is the Samding Dorje Phagmo. A certain text from this religion describes various "bardos" and is known as the Book of the Dead. The two largest traditions in this religion are the Red Hat and Yellow Hat schools. The current leader of this religion resides in Dharamshala, although his official residence is the Potala Palace. For 10 points, name this religious tradition currently led by Tenzin Gyatso, the Dalai Lama.
tossups.answer: Tibetan Buddhism [accept Nyingma; accept Yellow Hat, Red Hat, or Gelug before "Red Hat;" prompt on Mahayana Buddhism or Vajrayana Buddhism]

tossups.question: This theorem’s proof relies on a definition in which its formulator indirectly shows that a deformation ring, R, completely intersects a Hecke ring, T, allowing the use of Galois representations. Beal’s conjecture is a generalization of this theorem. Any counterexamples to this theorem lead to a curve which is semi-stable but not modular according to Ribet’s theorem. The (*) elliptical Frey curve corresponds to a solution to this theorem, which arose while attempting to disprove the related Taniyama-Shimura conjecture. Proven in 1994 by Andrew Wiles, for 10 points, name this theorem stating that, for n greater than 2, there are no positive integer solutions to the equation “x-to-the-n plus y-to-the-n equals z-to-the-n”.
tossups.answer: Fermat’s Last Theorem [accept Fermat’s conjecture; prompt on Fermat’s Theorem or FLT; do not accept or prompt on “Fermat’s Little Theorem”]

tossups.question: A leader of this country fell from power after he was arrested in the middle of the night while reading a translation of Mein Kampf in his bedroom. The fascist “Gold Shirts” supported that leader, who was opposed by the Feminine Brigades of St. Joan of Arc in a conflict ended through a series of breakfasts known as “ham-and-eggs” diplomacy. U.S. Ambassador Dwight Morrow mediated a rebellion against a (*) religious institution in this country. Collective lands called ejidos were distributed to people by a president of this country who nationalized its oil industry. This country’s Cristero War was initiated by Plutarco Calles. For 10 points, name this country, where Lazaro Cardenas established state oil company Pemex.

The 1982 collection Destroy debuted many outfits in this color, including tattered sweaters. In a Fall 2001 collection by Viktor & Rolf, models were covered head-to-toe in this color. Thierry Mugler designed an outfit of this color worn by Demi Moore in the film Indecent Proposal.  Rei Kawakubo and Yohji Yamamoto primarily work in this color. A dress of this color held together by four gold (*) safety pins and worn by Elizabeth Hurley at the premiere of Four Weddings and a Funeral is nicknamed “THAT dress.” Yves Saint Laurent’s “Le Smoking” outfit is primarily this color. Givenchy (“zhee-VAHN-shee”) designed a “little” dress of this color worn by Audrey Hepburn in Breakfast at Tiffany’s. For 10 points, name this color associated with goths.

The natural logarithm of this quantity at time "t" is given by an equation first put forward by Bennett McCallum and designed to perform during a crisis. The nominal expenditure is equal to this quantity multiplied by VT (V sub T) according to Irving Fisher's equation of exchange. In the Hicks–Hansen model, this quantity is paired with "liquidity preference" as one of the two central curves. The (*) "k % rule" holds that, irrespective of business cycles, this quantity should be increased at a fixed annual rate. A book by Anna Schwartz and Milton Friedman claimed that changes in this quantity had significant impacts on the economy, including inflation. For 10 points, name this quantity that measures the current amount of currency circulating in the economy.
tossups.answer: money supply [or monetary supply; or monetary base; or money stock; prompt on M, M0, M1, etc; prompt on money]

tossups.question: Margaretta Matilda Odell’s biography of this author is criticized as inaccurate in the essay “The Dear Pledges of Our Love,” which appears in the essay collection The Fire This Time. This poet described “breathing figures learnt from thee to live” after viewing a painting by Scipio Moorhead. A figure in a poem by this author “flashes dreadful in refulgent arms.” The line (*) “Hail, happy saint, on thine immortal throne” opens a poem by this author dedicated to the reverend George Whitefield. This author invokes Columbia after the line “Celestial choir! enthron’d in realms of light” in her poem “To His Excellency, George Washington.” For 10 points, name this Black female poet from colonial America.

bonuses.leadin: A set of eight 3-by-3 Hermitian matrices that generate the SU3 symmetry group of this interaction are named for Murray Gell-Mann. For 10 points each:
answer: strong nuclear force [or strong interaction; prompt on nuclear force]
quark-gluon plasma [or QGP; accept quark matter, quark liquid, or quark soup; do not prompt on plasma or gluon alone]
parts: Name this interaction whose magnitude increases with distance at high energies due to confinement. This interaction is responsible for holding protons and neutrons in the nucleus.

Unlike in traditional matter, particles affected by the strong force will experience deconfinement when in one of these substances. Matter must exceed the Hagedorn temperature to form one of these substances.

One method for analyzing the strong interaction is with the screened Yukawa potential, which contains terms for both the radius and the mass of these particles. These particles are the lightest hadrons.

bonuses.leadin: A commander at this battle died from sniper fire after remarking “they couldn’t hit an elephant at this distance”. For 10 points each:
answer: Ulysses S. Grant and Robert Edward Lee [accept Hiram Ulysses Grant]
parts: Name this 1864 battle where John Sedgwick was killed, making him the highest-ranking Union death during the Civil War. Horatio Wright’s troops fought desperately at this battle’s “Bloody Angle”.
These two generals fought each other at Spotsylvania Courthouse. They met again at Appomattox Courthouse.
Grant and Lee both fought in this battle that began the Overland Campaign. This battle was named for taking place in a heavily wooded area.

bonuses.leadin: The narrator of the second poem of this collection knows of “Egypt and Niger / Of Persia and Xenophon,” but prefers “the fresh mountain air’s caress.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this 1891 poetry collection which contains the poems “If You’ve Seen a Mount of Sea Foam” and “I Have a White Rose to Tend.”
Versos Sencillos is most notable for including a poem that became this patriotic song. It opens by mentioning a “sincere man” from “where the palm trees grow.”
Jose Marti wrote “Guantanamera,” a patriotic song from this Caribbean island country.

bonuses.leadin: This athlete was ranked #1 by the WTA for 377 weeks, the most for any male or female tennis player. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this German athlete, one of the greatest tennis players ever, who first reached #1 in 1987 after defeating Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert.

In 1988, Graf became the only tennis player to achieve the “Golden” type of this feat, which normally requires winning all four major championships in one calendar year. This two-word term can also be accomplished in golf.
After beating Graf in the finals of the 1993 Australian Open, this Yugoslavian player was stabbed during a match by an obsessive fan of Graf’s, sidelining her career for the next two years.

bonuses.leadin: A study by Pew Research Center suggested that, despite public perception, the local variety of this service is gradually dying off. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this type of service whose televised, local variety is often provided by affiliates of companies such as CBS, Fox, and ABC and which typically focus on crime and sports stories.

This controversial media conglomerate currently owns and operates news channels that reach 40% of American households. Mandatory programming for channels owned by this company include the Terrorism Alert Desk and several editorials by Michael Hyman.

In 2018, Sinclair attempted to buy this now-defunct media conglomerate before the FCC shot down their acquisition. This Chicago-based company previously owned newspapers such as the Los Angeles Times and Baltimore Sun, and was eventually purchased by Nexstar Media Group.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about some of the most difficult soprano roles in opera. For 10 points each:
parts: Mozart created the villainous Queen of the Night role from this opera for the soprano Josepha Hofer as a way of showing off her skillful coloratura and ability to sustain high F6 notes in arias like “Der Holle Rache”.

Sibyl Sanderson made her professional debut playing the title soprano of this opera by Jules Massenet. In this opera, the title Byzantine sorceress refuses the hand of Roland until he is able to win a tournament.

This operatic scene from Act 3 of Lucia di Lammermoor has historically been viewed as one of the most demanding for sopranos, which has prompted singers like Dame Joan Sutherland and Nellie Melba to appended cadenzas to end of its difficult aria Il dolce suono.

bonuses.leadin: A suspicious package in Ryazan sparked theories that these events may have been carried out by the government. For 10 points each:
answer: 1999 Russian apartment bombings [prompt on apartment bombings by asking “Where?”]
parts: Name these events that were blamed on the “Liberation Army of Dagestan”. Alexander Litvinenko claimed the government was behind these events in a book subtitled Terror from Within.
The apartment bombings were used as an excuse by this current president of Russia to invade Chechnya.
Putin garnered criticism for his handling of a hostage crisis in this type of place in Beslan, during which gunfire from Russian FSB likely killed 186 hostages.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about mathematics… in European literature, for 10 points each:
answer: All Quiet on the Western Front
Italo Calvino [the novel mentioned is Invisible Cities]
The Man Without Qualities [by Robert Musil]
parts: Paul Bäumer (“BOY-muhr”) asks “What use is it to him now that he was such a good mathematician in school?” after a soldier dies in this Erich Maria Remarque novel about the horrors of World War I.

This author’s collaborations with the Oulipo (“ooh-lee-PO”) group inspired him to use mathematics to sequence many of his works, including a novel where Marco Polo tells Kublai Khan about his trips to 55 of the title places.
During an existential crisis, the former mathematician Ulrich joins a committee that plans the celebration of Franz Josef I’s 70th birthday in this unfinished novel.

bonuses.leadin: In one technique, this quantity is measured for an analyte as a function of varying electrical potential over time. For 10 points each:
answer: electrochemical window [or EW; or solvent window or SW; anti-prompt “be less specific” on water window]
parts: Name this quantity that appears on the y-axis of plots produced in cyclic voltammetry experiments. More generally, this quantity equals the number of electrons passing through a detector over time.

Direct current is applied to drive a nonspontaneous chemical reaction in this process, which is commonly analyzed using cyclic voltammetry. When this process is applied to water, hydrogen and oxygen gases are produced.

This is one of the most important quantities when choosing a solvent for use in an electrochemical experiment, since it gives the voltage range in which the solvent will neither be oxidized nor reduced. This quantity equals the oxidation potential minus the reduction potential.

bonuses.leadin: One collaboration between these two authors begins with an old woman appearing at a family’s wedding to present an allegorical description of four “beautiful green fields.” For 10 points each:
answer: Lady Gregory and William Butler Yeats
Ireland [or Eire or Republic of Ireland or Poblacht na hÉireann]
airman [or aviator; or pilot; accept “An Irish Airman Foresees His Death”]
parts: Name these two authors who collaborated on the play Cathleen ni Houlihan. One of these two authors’ On Baile’s Strand was performed alongside the other’s Spreading the News on the opening night of the Abbey Theatre.
Both William Butler Yeats and Lady Gregory are writers in the literary tradition of this nation.
Yeats was likely inspired by the death of Lady Gregory’s only son to write a poem titled for an “Irish” person of this profession who “Foresees His Death.”

bonuses.leadin: The battle cry “Tongs ya bass!” was said in this city during a fight at a movie theater between two groups later consolidated under the gangster Arthur Thompson. For ten points:
answer: Kray Twins [Reginald “Reggie” Kray and Ronald “Ronnie” Kray]
homosexuality [accept sodomy, buggery; accept literally anything about being gay; an extra high-five if they say “being gay and doing crimes”]
parts: Name this non-Australian city where delinquent “neds” joined the infamous “razor gangs.”

Thompson once pulled up with a shotgun to a bar owned by these identical London gangsters after they threatened him, telling them “you’ll not forget me”. These twins gained fame both for their legitimate nightclub business and their racketeering.
Ronnie Kray was vilified by the London press for engaging in this practice after his affair with Lord Boothby was exposed. This practice was mostly decriminalized in the U.K. in 1967.

bonuses.leadin: Rajlich’s hypothesis claims that white lamellar structures inside certain minerals are indicative of this macroscopic process occurring. For 10 points each:
answer: asteroid/meteor impact [accept impact metamorphism or shock metamorphism; prompt on metamorphism or shock waves; do NOT accept or prompt on any answers mentioning volcanos or volcanic eruptions]
parts: Name this process that uniquely produces silicate minerals with planar deformation features.
Impact metamorphism can result in the creation of coesite and stishovite, two high-pressure polymorphs of this mineral with Mohs hardness of 7.

The Brazil pattern of this process, in which two crystal share lattice points and grow into one another, has been uniquely seen in types of quartz produced as a result of impact metamorphism. Carlsbad names a law of this process for orthoclase feldspars.

bonuses.leadin: According to correspondence theories, this property is present when the state of affairs are coherent with a proposition. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this property which is possessed by facts and is opposed to falsehood.

This logician and mathematician outlined the semantic theory of truth in his Logic, Semantics, Mathematics, which introduced his idea of Convention-T, or the idea that truth is a property held by statements.

Paul Benacerraf argued that Tarski's definition of truth was in line with this theory. This theory, which was espoused by Kurt Gödel, is a variant of mathematical realism, which holds that mathematical entities are abstract concepts that are unchanging and lack spatiotemporal properties.

bonuses.leadin: Note to player - multiple answers are required for the first part of this bonus. A Double Concerto dedicated to Robert Hausmann and Joseph Joachim makes use of a motif composed of these musical notes. For 10 points each:
answer: F-A-E [or any permutation of the letters A, E, and F; DO NOT accept or prompt on partial answers]
Natural horn or French horn  [DO NOT accept or prompt on “English horn”]
parts: Name these musical notes. A violin sonata titled after these musical notes was partially composed by Albert Dietrich and Robert Schumann and is based on Joseph Joachim’s personal motto of “free but lonely.”

The aforementioned Double Concerto and the Scherzo of the F-A-E sonata were composed by this German Romantic composer and frequent collaborator with Joseph Joachim, who along with Beethoven and Bach is one of the “Three B’s” of German composers.

Brahms wrote an unusual trio that is scored for violin, piano, and the “natural” variety of this brass instrument, which also features prominently in the final movement of his Brahms’s first symphony. A modern version of this instrument is the only brass instrument included in a standard wind quintet.

bonuses.leadin: During a holiday celebrating this figure, people form human pyramids and race to break a clay pot full of yogurt known as Dahi Handi. For 10 points each:
answer: Krishna [accept Krishna Janmashtami; accept Hare Krishna]
Bhagavata Purana [accept Bhagavatamahapuranam; accept Śrīmad Bhāgavatam; accept Srimad Bhagavata Mahapurana]
parts: Name this figure. A religious movement named for this figure was founded by Swami Prabhupada, and has followers who sing mantras named for this figure.

The story of Krishna, including Krishna Janmashtami, is found primarily in this Purana. This Purana details all the forms that Vishnu has assumed, and lists devotee’s who primarily venerated Vishnu and his separate avatars.
During Krishna Janmashtami, this activity is commonly performed during Rasa Lila. Variations of this activity like Bharatanatyam and Kuchipudi arose due to differences in choreography.

bonuses.leadin: Prisoners of war held at Fort Marion during the Red River War produced a form of “ledger art” designed to imitate drawings on the hides of these animals. For 10 points each:
answer: buffalo [or The Last of the Buffalo; accept American bison]
Yellowstone National Park [accept Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone]
Oklahoma (The group of artists is the Kiowa Six; the museum is Oklahoma City’s art museum)
parts: Name these large mammals. A native American on horseback dramatically thrusts a spear at one of these animals in a painting by Albert Bierstadt.

Bierstadt’s fellow Rocky Mountain school artist, Thomas Moran, is likely best-known for a painting that depicts the “Grand Canyon of [this national park]”. Other paintings of this national park by Moran commissioned by the US Geologic Survey are said to have inspired President Grant to federally protect this national park.

The Fort Marion ledger artists heavily inspired Stephen Mopope, a member of a group of six artists from this state that bridged ledger art with the flat-style of Plains art. A museum in this state houses a 55-foot blown glass tower by Dale Chihuly dedicated to its founder Eleanor Blake Kirkpatrick.

bonuses.leadin: In the case Rucho v. Common Cause, the Supreme Court ruled that the partisan form of this practice is nonjusticiable and may not be brought to federal court. For 10 points each:
parts: Give the common name for drawing congressional districts for partisan benefit. It is named after the governor of Massachusetts who served from 1810-1812.

According to a report from the Brookings Institute, gerrymandering in the United States has contributed to this political process. This is the process by which partisan differences increase and increasingly extreme views are taken.

This economist has argued for the idea of "asymmetric polarization" where one political party takes stances farther from the political center than the other. This former Secretary of Labor also wrote the books Reason and Supercapitalism.

bonuses.leadin: NOTE TO MODERATOR: Please read part 1 slowlyA classic experiment for determining this numeric value bound DNA to a piece of mica, fixed it in place, and added DNase to produce repeating bands separated by intervals of this value. For 10 points each:
answer: 10.5 base pairs per turn [accept answers between 9.5bp and 11.5bp]
x-ray(s) [accept x-ray interferometry or x-ray crystallography]
parts: Please give your answer in number of base pairs. Within one base pair, what is the number of base pairs in one full turn of the helix for the B form of DNA at normal physiological conditions?
This alternative form of DNA has a bp per turn closer to 12bp. Unlike the A and B forms, this conformation uniquely has a left-handed helix and only one large groove analogous to the major groove.

One technique for identifying the form that a sample of DNA is in does so by mixing the sample with gold nanoparticles and probing it with interferometry in this region of the EM spectrum. A crystallographic technique in this region of the EM spectrum was used by Rosalind Franklin for her pioneering images of DNA.

bonuses.leadin: This government was weakened by the Anarchy at Samarra, which allowed for the rise of Ahmad ibn Tulun in Egypt. For 10 points each:
answer: Qarmatian [or Karmatian or Karmathian or Qarmatī or Qarāmiṭah]
parts: Name this government, which faced a massive revolt of African slaves during the Zanj Rebellion.
The Abbasids established this city as their capital following the turmoil of the Anarchy of Samarra. This city was brutally sacked in 1258 by Hulagu Khan.

This group sacked Mecca in 930 and ransomed the Black Stone of the Ka’aba back to the Abbasids for an enormous amount. This Bahraini subsect of the Ismailis defiled the Zamzam Well by filling it with dead bodies.

bonuses.leadin: Short stories published in this magazine in the 1940s include J.D. Salinger’s “A Perfect Day for Bananafish” and Shirley Jackson’s “The Lottery.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this weekly magazine, known for its dry cartoons, that is based in the largest city in the U.S.
In 1947, The New Yorker published this short story by John Cheever about Irene Westcott, whose marriage deteriorates after she uses the title object to listen in on her neighbors’ conversations.

The New Yorker also published this 1942 story by James Thurber, in which Mr. Martin decides against killing Mrs. Barrows and instead tells her a fake plan to bomb their boss. Its title is now used as an idiom referring to having the upper hand in a situation.
